uist-8.sentence: Text entry is expected to be a common task for smart glass users, which is generally performed using a touchpad on the temple or by a promising approach using eye tracking.
uist-8.label: Background

uist-8.sentence: Text entry; Smart glasses; Gaze and Touch, Multi-modal input
uist-8.label: Background

uist-8.sentence: For more efcient text entry, we present the concept of gaze-assisted typing (GAT), which uses both a touchpad and eye tracking.
uist-8.label: Background

uist-8.sentence: However, each approach has its own limitations.
uist-8.label: Background

uist-8.sentence: We initially examined GAT with a minimal eye input load, and demonstrated that the GAT technology was 51% faster than a two-step touch input typing method ( i.e. ,M-SwipeBoard: 5.85 words per minute (wpm) and GAT: 8.87 wpm).
uist-8.label: Result

uist-8.sentence: Finally, we compared GAT with touch-only typing (SwipeZone) and eye-only typing (adjustable dwell) using an eye-trackable head-worn display.
uist-8.label: Method

uist-8.sentence: The results showed that a GAT requiring ve different touch gestures was the most preferred, although all GAT techniques were equally efcient.
uist-8.label: Result

uist-8.sentence: We also compared GAT methods with varying numbers of touch gestures.
uist-8.label: Result

uist-8.sentence: The results demonstrate that the most preferred technique, GAT, was 25.4% faster than the eye-only typing and 29.4% faster than the touch-only typing (GAT: 11.04 wpm, eye-only typing: 8.81 wpm, and touch-only typing: 8.53 wpm).
uist-8.label: Result
